CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 2 (obligation to protect the right to life);Violation of Art. 2 (obligation to provide an effective investigation);Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in the village of Khokholskiy in LOC . He is the father of PERSON , who was found dead on DATE in a punishment cell of the prison where he had been serving his sentence . He had died of asphyxia caused by hanging . At the time of his death , PERSON was DATE and was due to be released DATE .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON was remanded in custody in connection with criminal charges brought against him .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON was convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to DATE imprisonment . He was serving his sentence in the correctional labour colony ( исправительно-трудовая колония ) OZH CARDINAL/CARDINAL in PERSON , GPE . He expected to be released on probation on DATE .

CARDINAL . According to the records submitted by the Government , on QUANTITY occasions in DATE PERSON had been found to be under the influence of alcohol and placed in a punishment cell . During his second disciplinary confinement , PERSON inflicted bodily injury on himself , and during his third disciplinary confinement he attempted suicide ( see the section entitled “ Medical records ” ) .
CARDINAL . Following the suicide attempt , PERSON was placed under regular psychiatric supervision .
CARDINAL . On DATE a prison football team , of which PERSON was a member , took part in a match outside the prison .

CARDINAL . On return to the prison after the match , PERSON was found to be under the influence of alcohol . At TIME a prison officer placed him in a punishment cell where he was to be kept in solitary confinement before his inspection by the prison warder TIME . At TIME PERSON was found dead , hanged by the sleeve of his jacket with another sleeve attached to a water pipe .

CARDINAL . That evening the prison governor conducted an inquest . He examined CARDINAL documents : ( i ) the order to place PERSON in the punishment cell , ( ii ) the disciplinary offence report , ( iii ) the report drawn up on finding PERSON , ( iv ) the site inspection report , ( v ) the site plan and ( vi ) the post mortem report . On the basis of this file , he stated that PERSON had hanged himself using the sleeve of his jacket and ordered that no criminal investigation be opened , as there had been no appearance that a crime had been committed . A reference was also made to his attempted suicide in DATE , and it was stated that he had had suicidal tendencies .

CARDINAL . On DATE an autopsy was performed on the body . In DATE a post mortem report was issued according to which abrasions and bruises were found on the nose , hand , forearm and elbow . The expert came to the conclusion that death had been caused by pressure on the neck through hanging .

CARDINAL . The applicant was informed orally that his son had committed suicide . He asked the prison authorities to initiate a criminal investigation . The authorities did not inform him that a decision had already been taken not to do so .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant requested ORG to provide him with information about the circumstances of his son ’s death . The request was transmitted to GPE supervising penitentiary institutions .

He was also informed that , in the circumstances , the decision not to institute a criminal investigation was lawful and well - founded .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant of the refusal to institute criminal proceedings and invited him , on DATE , to view the case file concerning the death of his son .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant arrived at the prosecutor ’s office for the appointment to view the file , but the officer in charge was absent and he could not gain access to the file .

CARDINAL . After the case had been communicated to the respondent Government by ORG , ORG annulled the decision of CARDINAL DATE on DATE and instituted a criminal investigation into PERSON death .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought proceedings before the same district court to have the refusal of the prison governor to institute criminal proceedings declared unlawful .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE held that the decision of CARDINAL DATE was unlawful . At the same time it discontinued the examination of the applicant ’s claim as no longer necessary , given the prosecutor ’s decision of DATE which had already dealt with the issue .

CARDINAL . In DATE CARDINAL forensic examinations were carried out . First , experts were appointed to conduct a new autopsy of the body . Secondly , another group of experts carried out a posthumous examination of PERSON psychiatric and psychological condition .

CARDINAL . The autopsy resulted in substantially the same findings as the first post mortem report , namely , that the death had been caused by mechanical asphyxia ( more specifically , strangling ) , and established a mediumdegree alcoholic intoxication at the time of death .

CARDINAL . On DATE the posthumous psychiatric report was submitted . The experts concluded that at the time of his death PERSON had not been predisposed to suicide on account of any long or short - term psychiatric disorder . However , they concluded that he had been under the influence of alcohol and that it could have triggered his decision to commit suicide .
CARDINAL . During the investigation the following witnesses were examined and gave the following testimonies :

( i ) Six officers who were on duty at the prison entrance when PERSON returned to the prison after the football match , testified that he had been drunk and had behaved aggressively . He therefore had to be isolated in the punishment cell . They all stated that no force had been applied to him .

( ii ) CARDINAL inmates who had been on the same football team testified that PERSON had been under the influence of alcohol on their return from the match , and that was why he had been stopped by the prison warders at the prison entrance . They stated that there had been no threats or violence at the prison entrance .

( iii ) CARDINAL other inmates who had known PERSON well testified that he had had good relations with other inmates and warders and that there had been no conflict between him and the prison administration .

( iv ) Six officers who had been on duty in the punishment ward when PERSON died , testified that he had been placed in the cell at TIME and had been found dead during the warder ’s round at TIME They stated that first aid had been administered , but that it had been too late .

( v ) Inmates PERSON and PERSON testified that they had been confined to punishment cells next to PERSON . PERSON stated that at first they had communicated through the wall , but then PERSON had gone quiet . Neither of them had heard any noises or screams .

( vii ) CARDINAL officers testified that they had witnessed PERSON previous suicide attempt in DATE and administered first aid to him . They considered that that attempt had not been a genuine suicide , but that he had rather been trying to attract attention and demonstrate his independence .

( viii ) Ms. PERSON , the psychiatrist who had supervised PERSON , testified that his first suicide attempt had been demonstrative and had not reflected a genuine wish to die . She also considered , on the basis of her observations , that he had been likely to make another attempt , also demonstrative and not aimed at causing death , and that the probability of such behaviour increased under the influence of alcohol .
CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE Special Prosecutor ’s Office supervising penitentiary institutions terminated the criminal investigation , having established that PERSON had committed suicide .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW of GPE protects the right to life .

CARDINAL . The Health Care ( General Principles ) Act of DATE provides that persons serving a sentence in prisons are entitled to medical assistance at the ORG ’s expense and , as the case may be , at institutions run by the general public health service ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . The Law on Penitentiary Institutions of DATE provides that penitentiary institutions are responsible for inmates’ security and health care ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . DATE Penitentiary Code , as it read at the material time , provided that inmates suffering from a psychiatric disorder which did not affect their capacity to serve a criminal sentence could be subjected to medical treatment at the penitentiary institutions . The authorisation of a competent court was required for any such treatment .

After recent amendments , the same provision specifies that such inmates include persons who pose a danger to others or themselves . The provisions currently in force require the penitentiary authorities to identify such inmates and to apply for a court order imposing medical treatment on them .

CARDINAL The DATE Code of Criminal Procedure , which was in force at the material time , required that a competent authority institute criminal proceedings if there was a suspicion that a crime had been committed . That authority was under an obligation to carry out all measures provided for by law to establish the facts and to identify those responsible and secure their conviction . The decision whether or not to institute criminal proceedings had to be taken within DATE of the first report on the relevant facts ( Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . No criminal proceedings could be brought in the absence of a corpus delicti ( LAW . Where an investigating body refused to open or terminated a criminal investigation , a reasoned decision was to be provided . Such decisions could be appealed to a higher - ranking prosecutor or to a court ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .
